thread.title: Travel immunizations shouldn't wait until 10 minutes before boarding
thread.title_full: Travel immunizations shouldn't wait until 10 minutes before boarding | OregonLive.com

author: Terry Richard | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: Travel immunizations shouldn't wait until 10 minutes before boarding
text:
Passport, visa, air ticket, time away . . . planning travel gets complicated.
One more complication: don't forget the immunizations you need, especially for travel in the tropics, or just general preventive medicine for active time on the go away from home.
The obvious place to start is with your primary care physician and clinic, but it can quickly get more complicated than that. So that's where the Travel and Immunization Clinic of Portland enters the fray.
That was the message brought to the Here and There Travel Fest by clinic manager Linda Boring last weekend when the show was held at the Oregon Convention Center. The clinic is very specialized in what it does, but is there to help travelers who need that special attention.
The clinic staff is trained to determine what pre-trip to post-trip care that travelers need, depending on destination and medical and other personal history. According to Boring, primary care providers often don't even attempt to keep up with vaccinations for hepatitis, cholera or diphtheria, let alone the less common but still serious illnesses that lurk on the road.
The clinic also follows weekly changes in recommended medications for world travelers, as made by government and health agencies. "Most primary care clinics just can't keep up with that kind of detail,'' said Boring, who takes her name from the family that gave its name to a town in Clackamas County.
When travel requires special medical planning, Boring advises beginning the process four to six weeks before departure. But not everyone does that.
"We had one patient show up for a 10:10 a.m. appointment and told us he had to be at the airport at 12:45 p.m. the same day. We did the best we could,'' she said.
The clinic, founded in 2003, is at 2330 N.W. Flanders St., No. 103, Portland; 503-227-7771; travelhealthnw.com .
